The Scripps National Spelling Bee defines normal school activity as adherence to at least four courses of study other than language arts, spelling, Latin, Greek, vocabulary, and etymology for at lease four hours per weekday for 34 of the 38 weeks between September 1,2009, and May 23, 2010".

PUSD BOARD VOTES TO PLACE PARCEL TAX ON MAY 4 BALLOT Measure Would Protect Schools, Libraries, Arts & Music Facing the most severe reduction in funding from the State of California in its history, the Pasadena Unified School District (PUSD) Board of Education voted unanimously to place a local parcel tax on the May 4, 2010 election ballot. Because of an 18 percent overall cut in funding to public schools in California, PUSD faces up to $23 million in cuts to its schools and programs. “When Sacramento fails to fund our schools by more than $20 million, we must take steps to ensure that every student continues to have access to a great education,” said Board President Tom Selinske. “The successes and milestones we’ve seen in our schools deserve stable, local funding so that we can attract and retain qualified teachers, protect college preparatory programs, keep libraries open and continue offering arts and music.” The Quality Public Education Preservation Act of 2010 would levy a $120 tax per residential and commercial parcel each year for five years, with exemptions for low-income seniors, and raise an estimated $7.1 million annually beginning in the 2010-2011 year. All funds would benefit PUSD schools and students. The parcel tax requires approval by two-thirds of Altadena, Pasadena and Sierra Madre voters. Monies raised would be used to preserve educational opportunities that prepare local students to succeed in college and careers; continue funding academic programs in advanced math, science, technology, music and art; keep school libraries open, and lessen the impact of state budget cuts. Visit www.pusd.us for more information

Board approves levy for May 4 ballot On Monday, January 25, the Board of Education adopted a resolution "determining to proceed with submission of a substitute tax levy." Collection of the two emergency levies generating $14.3 million and $4 million, respectively, per year, expire in Dec. 2010. The original $14.3 million levy cost the taxpayer 13.4 mills when it was approved five years ago. Three years ago, the $4 million levy cost the taxpayer 4.42 mills when it was approved, for combined total of 17.82 mills. The combined fixed-sum dollar amount of these levies, $18.3 million, which is approximately 26% of the MCSD operating budget. The Board of Education wishes to combine and substitute these levies for a total of 17.51 mills, which is less than the combined total for the two separate levies. In summary, the current emergency levies will be combined and exchanged for a substitute levy, on a continuing basis. The original $14.3 million levy cost the taxpayer 13.4 mills when it was approved five years ago. Three years ago, the $4 million levy cost the taxpayer 4.42 mills when it was approved. What exactly is a Substitute Levy? A Substitute Levy is new to Ohio. A district can substitute or exchange an Emergency Levy renewal with a substitute levy. This Substitute Levy is identical to the original emergency levy with two exceptions - as new valuation growth is seen in the district by only new construction, the additional dollar value is added to the original value of the levy. The Substitute Levy is not subject to HB 920 which keeps the dollar amount that the district receives the same each year.

The latest architectural designs for the new auditorium at Ritenour High School have been posted on the Ritenour Bond Issue Web site. The drawings feature a detailed rendition of the exterior of the building, as well as a view of the inside of the new auditorium. At its regular meeting in January, the Ritenour Board of Education approved a bid for $18.4 million from C. Rallo Contracting Company Inc. to build the new facility. The project schedule calls for the auditorium to be completed by July 1, 2011.

Former Carroll Dragons kicker Garrett Hartley made history Sunday night and became a New Orleans hero. He sent the Saints to their first Super Bowl with a game-winning 40-yard FG in overtime to defeat Minnesota 31-28 in the NFC Championship. Hartley and the Saints will face the Colts in Super Bowl XLIV Feb. 7 in Miami. Ex-Dragons quarterback Chase Daniel is also a member of the Saints. Congrats to the Dragon alums.

Fifty school board members from around Wisconsin attended a session conducted by the Ripon Board of Education at the Wisconsin Association of School Boards (WASB) annual convention in Milwaukee to learn about the homework initiative in our schools during the past 3 years. The audience was intensely interested and very impressed with Ripon. Nice job!

There are currently 86 Open Enrollment students attending Ripon schools, and over 50 additional seats are available for new Open Enrollment applications for 2010-11. Nine of the 14 grade levels have space for new Open Enrollment students. The five grade levels closed to new applications are: grade 1, 3, 4, 9, 10. Contact Karin at 920-748-4600 for more information about Open Enrollment to Ripon. Share this with a friend.

Duluth East captured the boys title and the Greyhounds finished runner-up in the girls competition at the Duluth High School Nordic Skiing Invitational on Friday in Duluth. Duluth Central finished fifth and Duluth Denfeld ninth in boys, and Duluth Central ninth and Duluth Denfeld 11th in girls. Duluth Eeast finished 1-2-4-5 in the boys competition, and Marian Lund of Duluth East was the girls individual champion.

The Duluth Northern Stars lost to the Proctor-Hermantown-Marshall Mirage 4-2 in a Minnesota Hockey Day high school girls hockey game played outdoors Saturday in Hermantown. Frankie Bergman and Jane Goldfarb scored goals for the Northern Stars.
Rochester Lourdes defeated Duluth Central 7-0 in a non-conference high school hockey game Friday at Heritage Arena.

Duluth East defeated Duluth Denfeld 63-58 in a high school girls basketball game Saturday. The Hunters led 38-29 at halftime. Alex Freeman had 25 points for Duluth East, and Leah Ham scored a team-high 20 points for Duluth Denfeld.
Duluth Denfeld lost to visiting Rochester Lourdes 4-2 in a non-conference high school hockey game on Saturday at Heritage Arena.

LETTER FROM THE MIDDLETOWN HEALTH DEPARTMENT Dear Parents/Guardian: We would like to thank you for your help and cooperation with the H1N1 Clinics. The Middletown City Health Department, with the help of our community partners, has successfully conducted H1N1 vaccination clinics in our schools and in the community. In order for us to feel confident that we have reached all students who are interested in the H1N1 vaccine, the Middletown City Health Department will be returning to our schools to vaccinate any remaining students who are interested. This will also give us the opportunity to give the 2nd dose of the vaccine to children under the age of 10 who received the first dose in December. If you are interested in having your child receive the first vaccine, or the 2nd dose, please complete the reverse side (even if you sent back a consent form earlier) and return it to your child's school. If your child will be receiving his/her 2nd dose of H1N1, please have him/her bring the card noting the date of the previous vaccination. If you have any questions or concerns about the H1N1 vaccine or the clinics, please call the Middletown Health Department at 513-425-1831. The clinic schedule is at: http://www.middletowncityschools.com/administration/departments/community_relations/:=:https://www.middletowncityschools.com Sincerely, David Winfough, Health Commissioner Jackie Phillips, Director of Nursing Middletown City Health Department

(Cont.) Vote NOW for McCaskill and Hart at http://www.mtvu.com/on-campus/oscars-student-correspondent-red-carpet-contest-2010/. Individuals can only vote once a day. The deadline to vote is February 10. Voting will end on Friday, February 10, at 5 p.m. On February 1, the top three finalists will be selected. The finalists will be flown to Los Angeles to take part in the events of the weekend, and one winning team will be chosen to cover the 82nd Annual Academy Awards® from the Red Carpet.

Mr. FAMU, Brandon McCaskill, and Kiarra Hart are competing for a chance to be a Red Carpet Correspondent at the 2010 Oscars® on March 7. This is FAMU’s second consecutive year competing in this contest AND being selected as a top 10 finalists. FAMU also is the only historically black college or university competing against other major universities in the nation.

Free Student Tickets To Florida State Fair-- The Florida State Fair is providing free student admission tickets. The tickets are for admission between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m. on Monday, February 15. The tickets are for one admission per student. February 15 is a student holiday and there are no classes scheduled for that day. The tickets are expected to arrive in schools by Friday, January 22. Contact individual schools for further information about their school’s ticket distribution process. Children ages five and younger are also free but visitors must obtain a complimentary admission for these children at the Fair ticket window. A standard admission fee applies for adults accompanying students with free fair tickets. Visit www.floridastatefair.net:=:https://www.floridastatefair.net/ for further information.

LCICS Charter Renewal Hearing This Evening (1.20.2010) at 7pm Location: Multi-Use Room at Middletown Unified School District This evening is LCICS’s Renewal Public Hearings at MUSD our sponsoring district. It is important that we have a strong showing of support at this Public Hearing as well as the second Hearing on February 24th. We ask that you do not let this inclement weather deter you from attending! Strong support for the renewal of our charter is extremely important! We are asking parents, grandparents, children and community members to speak on behalf of LCICS’s Charter Renewal for another five years. The best approach is anecdotal, through a short story about LCICS having a strong positive impact on your child, yourself and/or the community (a minute and a half -to- two minutes in duration). Short and to the point is always best leaving the MUSD Board with a positive, uplifting feeling about LCICS. If you know of other people that might speak on behalf of LCICS at our Charter Renewal Public Hearing please contact them and let them know of the importance of this evenings Hearing. The Public Hearing is tonight beginning at 7:00 pm in the MUSD Multi-Use Room right on the corner of Calistoga Rd. and Wardlaw. The Multi-Use Room is right next to Minnie Canyon Elementary School on the MUSD site in Middletown. If you can come a few minutes early that would be great (6:45-6:50 pm) and get a front row seat. We thank you for your support! Click on the attached map below (map is not exactly to scale): Minnie Cannon Elementary School 15846 Wardlaw Street Middletown, CA 95461 (707) 987-4130

The Ritenour Early Childhood Center again received accreditation by the National Association for the Education of Young Children (NAEYC) – meaning the program remains nationally accredited. According to the NAEYC Web site, Ritenour is one of only a dozen school districts in the state of Missouri to earn national accreditation – and only one of three in the St. Louis area. The program received a perfect score from NAEYC assessors.

HSC Encourages Support for Haiti Relief Efforts HSC is monitoring the situation in Haiti to determine ways that HSC faculty, staff and students can help. The disaster that has hit the island nation of Haiti is nothing short of horrific. Our hearts go out to the people of Haiti and to the many citizens of other countries who have been working there to help improve the lives of Haitians. We know everyone is very concerned about the tragedy, so this web page is being used to keep all of us informed on the latest developments. Many in our community have inquired about ways in which they can help to provide assistance for the international relief efforts being mounted in response to this disaster. The UNM School of Medicine's Office of Global Health Programs http://hsc.unm.edu/som/programs/globalhealth/index.shtml:=:https://hsc.unm.edu/som/programs/globalhealth/index.shtml has assembled a list of organizations that are accepting donations they will use to provide direct relief for Haiti. For those interested in helping immediately, simply text "HAITI" to "90999" and a donation of $10 will be given automatically to the Red Cross to help with relief efforts, charged to your cell phone bill, or text "YELE" to "501501" and a donation of $5 will be given automatically to Yéle Haiti to help with relief efforts. If you are a health care provider and you are interested in volunteering to help out, here are the official links for volunteer registration for the Haiti Disaster: http://www.cidi.org/incident/haiti-10a/:=:https://www.cidi.org/incident/haiti-10a/ http://www.usaid.gov/locations/latin_america_caribbean/country/haiti/eq/:=:https://www.usaid.gov/locations/latin_america_caribbean/country/haiti/eq/ http://hsc.unm.edu/SOM/cdm/nmdmat.shtml:=:https://hsc.unm.edu/som/cdm/nmdmat.shtml

The Health Sciences Center web site is now smart-phone compatible with a new version of the site designed for mobile devices. The upgrade enables HSC faculty and staff members to quickly navigate and effectively access important site information while “on the fly.” The mobile site will work on the top handheld devices on the market today, including: Blackberry Storm and Curve, Motorola’s Droid, and Apple’s iPhone and iPod Touch. The new site marks the Health Science Library and Informatics Center’s increased emphasis on using mobile technologies to help students, faculty and staff find the information and resources they need. Links to the UNM directory, HSC Calendar, classroom schedules, HSC webmail, social media, library resources (such as the online catalog, PubMed, CINAHL and Dynamed) and others are live and active. Future additions will include interactive campus maps and more library resources for faculty and students. The mobile-site URL is http://m.health.unm.edu.:=:https://m.health.unm.edu./ For more information, call 272-3683.

In the News Tribune’s Swimming Honor Roll, published today, Jack Malban of Duluth is fifth in the 200 Individual Medley (2:21.59), and Anthony Vecchi is second in the 100 Butterfly (58.92) and third in the 100 Breaststroke (1:11.09). Duluth is fourth in the 200 Yard Medley Relay (1:53.02) and 200 Freestyle Relay (1:40.13) and fifth in the 400 Freestyle Relay (3:49.8).
Duluth Northern Stars goaltender Paige Turner is first in saves percentage (.946) and second in goals-against (1.67).

Keith Tomassoni and Levi Talarico of Duluth Denfeld are tied for eighth in boys hockey scoring, with 25 points each. Freshman goaltender Zach Thompson is first in goals-against average (1.39) and saves percentage (.944). Jo Jo Jeannetta of Duluth East is sixth in goals against (2.32).

Three Tobey 3rd Graders started a fundraiser for an orphanage in Haiti several days ago. They expected to raise a few dollars in change but when the earthquake hit it all changed. The girls were on Channel 3 news and now people have stated to donate to the fundraiser. The girls and entire Tobey Community are enthused about the opportunity to "Offer a Helping Hand". The following message was sent by Mrs. McDaniel (the girls teacher). How fateful that the girls in my classroom has started the fundraiser for God's Little Angel's Orphanage just days before the earthquake. If you would like to see the website for this orphanage and check out the updates that they are posting about their condition (right hand side of the site) here is the website: Thank you for your support in your classrooms! Lynn http://glahaiti.org/:=:https://www.glahaiti.org/ If you would like to offer a donation please contact the Tobey Office or you can donate directly. Checks can be made out to Tobey Elementary.

Auditions are open for UNM’s first ever "You Got Talent?" - a UNM-only talent show benefiting the Health Sciences Center’s Center For Life Preventive and Integrative Medicine Specialty Clinic. UNM, UNMH, HSC and UNMMG, students, faculty, staff, alumni and immediate family members are invited and encouraged to “break a leg” on stage for a chance to win a $500 first prize; $300 second prize; or $200 third prize – and the opportunity to perform on Albuquerque’s big stage, Popejoy Hall.

This morning’s weather was the worst-case scenario. At 8 a.m. buses were picking up students. At 8:25 it began to snow again and a lot of students were headed to school. Our concern was that parents might have already left for work and if buses were sent back students would be at home alone or worse, unable to get into their home. We apologize for any inconvenience this morning’s weather may have caused your family.

It’s the time of year when snowflakes pop up suddenly on weather forecasts. What’s a student’s family or employee to do when delays or closings are possible? Go directly to an NNPS source for information. For announcements on school closings, delays, cancellations, postponements, early closings, and reporting times, visit the NNPS web site: www.nnschools.org, call the NNPS Information Line: (757) 283-7810 or the Administration Building main line: (757) 591-4500, or watch NNPS-TV on Cox Cable Channel 47 or Verizon Fios Channel 17. When bad weather is forecast overnight, transportation staffers begin checking streets at 4 a.m. to determine conditions. City police and emergency operations staff and local meteorologists may be contacted, too. The superintendent makes the decision to delay the opening of school, close schools early, or cancel school. NNPS tries to have a decision by 6 a.m. so television and radio stations can broadcast the information.

Students and staff will soon be able to get shots for the H1N1 Influenza (swine flu). School-based shot clinics are now being scheduled for late January through February. The H1N1 flu season is expected to continue through April, so it’s not too late to get vaccinated. The shots are free. The only requirement is that parents and staff fill out a consent form, available in both English and Spanish on the APS Web site. Schools will notify staff and families when shot clinics are scheduled.

Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts today selected 14 teams of arts organizations and school systems from across the nation to participate in the Partners in Education Institute, May 5-8, 2010 at the Kennedy Center. The School District of Janesville and the Young Auditorium at UW-Whitewater is one of the 14 teams selected. “This acceptance is recognition of the quality of your work as well as your potential to develop or expand professional development programs for teachers.”

Today the White House announced a $250 million initiative to improve science & math teaching. The $4 billion Race to the Top federal grant competition gives states bonus points for proposals that stress STEM (Science, Tech, Engineering, and Math) instruction. In an effort to keep our educational programs on course, Dr. Joe Morton, State Superintendent of Education plans to apply for Race to the Top by the phase I deadline of January 19th. According to Dr. Morton, "If we lose momentum in our classrooms, we could well lose a generation of students and that is totally unacceptable." What are your thoughts will this give a major relief to our classroom instruction and help the U.S. stay competitive with the world?

Marianne Evans, a special ed teacher at Manzano, will be recognized tonight by the APS Board of Ed for her heroic rescue of a student in cardiac arrest. Marianne gave CPR to the freshman for about 15 minutes before he was transported by ambulance to the hospital. MHS trainer Amy Hutton and athletics director Bob Kelly also helped, using the school's automated external defibrillator (AED). Way to go!

Let's add in, too, that the 2009 national championship is the latest in a string of successes for Putnam City North cheerleaders. The team won national championships in 2008, 2007, 2006 and 2005. Putnam City North cheerleaders also won state championships in 2009, 2008 and 2006, and in 2005 the squad won the state academic championship.

Putnam City North High Schools cheerleaders won their fifth national championship in a row over the holidays, taking first place in the small advanced varsity division of the National Cheerleaders Association Senior and Junior High School National Championships at the Dallas Convention Center. The Putnam City North cheerleaders also won awards for Best Showmanship and Best Use of Partner Stunts.

Mt. Peak is having our annual blood drive with Carter BloodCare January 8, 2010. This is open to staff, parents, and the community. The mobile unit will park in the employee parking lot. The sign-up times are in 15 minute increments with 2 people every 15 minutes. The first time slot is 8:15 and the last is 3:00. Donat...ing blood is truly giving a gift that saves lives. See web site for details. http://www.midlothian-isd.net/mtpeak/index.html

We are sad to share the news that former Tom McCall teacher Wayne Wallner died early this morning. Services will be this Sunday at 1 p.m. at Fuiten, Hoyt, Rose Funeral Home. There will be a reception afterwards at Tom McCall East. Wayne graduated from Forest Grove High School in 1965 and began his teaching career at Neil Armstrong in 1985. He taught 6th grade at Tom McCall from 1995 until he retired in 2003.

It's also a time to rediscover the strength & conviction within each of us and to pursue our goals with renewed purpose. Don’t shy away from the challenges but meet each head on.

SOUTHWEST FLORIDA – The Screaming Orphans, a high-spirited band of four sisters from County Donegal, Ireland, will rock the Sydney & Berne Davis Art Center on Friday, January 29 for “A Night Downtown” presented by the Rotary Club of Fort Myers. Beginning at 7:30 p.m., proceeds from the event benefiting the PACE of Lee County.

FORT MYERS, FL – Now thru Sunday, January 3, the Ft. Myers SteinMart location on the corner of US-41 and Cypress Lake Drive is collecting new or gently used blue jeans as part of the retailer’s denim sale. All denim donations will be given to girls, ages 12 to 18, served by the PACE Center for Girls of Lee County.

Duluth East lost to Stillwater Area 50-32 in girls basketball Tuesday at Hill-Murray. Shamika Hopkins had eight points and Macie Dorow seven to lead the Greyhounds, who trailed 29-12 at the half.

Duluth Central defeated Blake 59-55 in the Wood City Classic in Cloquet. Standout junior guard Darcell Williams led the Trojans with 23 points, and Ben Poppen chipped in with 16 points and Sam Hughes 11. Duluth Central will face St. Paul Humboldt at 4 p.m. today.

In boys basketball, Duluth East will face St. Cloud Tech today at 8 p.m. in the Granite City Classic in St. Cloud. The Greyhounds defeated Forest Lake 78-72 in the semis on Tuesday, as Dyami Starks scored 29, Nick Toland 20 and Johnny Woodard 17.

Duluth East lost to Hill-Murray 5-1 in a Schwan Cup Gold Division consolation game Tuesday at Xcel Energy Center in St. Paul. the Greyhounds play Holy Angels in the seventh-place game at 12:30 p.m. today in Brooklyn Park.
Duluth Central defeated La Crescent 11-1 on Tuesday in the Kiwanis/Wells Fargo Festival boys hockey tournament in Rochester. The Trojans lost to Mason City (IA) 6-0 in an opening-round game Monday.

Middletown City Schools May Operating levy to replace expiring collections On Monday, Dec. 21, the Board of Education passed the first of two resolutions necessary to put an operating levy on the May ballot. Collection of two emergency levies generating $14.3 million and $4 million, respectively, per year, expire in Dec. 2010. The combined fixed-sum total of these levies, $18.3 million, is approximately 26.5% of the MCSD operating budget. The Board of Education wishes to combine and substitute these levies. In summary, the current emergency levies will be combined and exchanged for a Substitute levy, on a continuing basis. WHAT EXACTLY IS A SUBSTITUTE LEVY? A Substitute levy is new to Ohio. A district can substitute or exchange an emergency levy renewal with a substitute levy. This substitute levy is identical to the original emergency levy with two exceptions - as new valuation growth is seen in the district by only new construction, the additional value is added to the original value of the levy. The term of this substitute levy is continuing. Before the Issue is actually placed on the ballot, the Board must approve a resolution to proceed. This will occur after the Butler County Auditor calculates the millage needed for the district to collect the needed millage for a combined fixed-sum total of $18.3 million. http://www.middletowncityschools.com/administration/schoolboard/:=:https://www.middletowncityschools.com

At the Board of Education meeting held November 23, 2009, two I Make a Difference awards were acknowledged. Susan Yazel is a current substitute for Derby Public Schools as well as a retired USD 260 educator. Ms. Yazel has devoted herself and her efforts to the well being of Oaklawn Elementary School. Ms. Yazel helps out during enrollment, making phone calls to families who have yet to enroll in a timely manner. As a substitute teacher she works extra hard, often staying past contract time to grade papers and get things in order for the returning teacher. Susan is an individual whose efforts are vital to the success of Oaklawn Elementary. Sisie Holliday somehow discovered that the El Paso health room had a low supply of replacement clothing for students who come to the health room with spills or accidents, which require a change of clothes. One day, she surprised the El Paso health room by bringing in neatly laundered and folded, coordinated outfits, each labeled by size and gender. On numerous occasions since, she has unexpectedly stopped by the health room with more clothing! Thanks to all our volunteers throughout the district!! To nominate an individual for an I Make a Difference Award click here: http://derbyschools.com/modules/cms/pages.phtml?pageid=141907&sessionid=218c65cf91d0ed4a78a1b092233b262c:=:https://derbyschools.com/modules/cms/pages.phtml?pageid=141907&sessionid=218c65cf91d0ed4a78a1b092233b262c

Students recite the School Pledge and Learner's Creed every Friday at our morning Assembly. STA School Pledge: We believe with all our hearts in our people, our teachers, our leaders and the righteousness and victory of our struggle. We must define ourselves, name ourselves, create for ourselves, speak for ourselves, instead of being defined, named, created and spoken for by others. We will work, study, and listen so we may learn. Learn so we may teach. Take pride in Sojourner Truth Academy. Learner’s Creed: I believe in myself and my ability to do my best at all times. Just for today I WILL LISTEN, I WILL SPEAK, I WILL FEEL, I WILL THINK, I WILL READ, I WILL WRITE! I will do all these things with one purpose in mind. TO DO MY BEST, AND TO NOT WASTE THIS DAY FOR THIS DAY WILL COME NO MORE.

Carver Elementary first-graders have the beat – and the rhythm – thanks to a program whose goal is to change lives through music. The after-school offering at Carver is the pilot program for Soundscapes, an organization born this year and inspired by programs in Venezuela and Baltimore. The goal of Soundscapes isn’t so much musical proficiency as it is social change. It offers after-school music instruction, but the program has higher goals.

JV also won their meet 60-39. Scott F. won the 200 Free and 100 Breast, Elliott Y. took the 50 Free and Casey the 100 Free. The Marlins are idle for the holiday break and resume action Wednesday, January 6 at Brown Deer.

Also in second place was the 200 Medley “B” Relay of Matthew O., Tristan M., Dawson and Ian 2:01.64, Matt in the 200 IM 2:13.78, diver Allan D. 177.4 points, Matthew in the 100 Free 0:56.53, the 200 Free “B” Relay of Dan, Casey V., Triston and Matthew 1:50.19 and Casey in the 100 Back 1:16.47.

Tom H. won the diving with 183.05 points. Jasen claimed the 200 IM 2:07.56 and finished second in the 500 Free 5:22.00. Jared led off the second place 400 Free “B” Relay with Chris, Dan B. and Ian S. 3:57.30. Ian took the 100 Breast 1:07.02 and was third in the 100 Free 0:58.58.

The Marlins captured first and second place in every event, and swept ten of the twelve. Alex won the 50 Free 0:22.44 and 500 Free 4:58.72 and led off the victorious 200 Medley Relay with Jasen, Jared M. and Matt 1:48.77. Josh took the 200 Free 1:57.15 and 100 Free 0:54.27 and anchored the winning 200 Free Relay of Dawson M., Chris K. and Jared 1:42.42.

The one event coach didn’t stray from was the 400 Free Relay which broke a pool record. Matt S., Josh S., Jasen J. and Alex R. swam the event in 3:18.91 breaking the former record of 3:21.09 set last season by Byron B., Matt, Jasen and Alex.

One of RGHS's 9th grade teams presented their final projects on the Harvey House in New Mexico on Friday, Dec. 11. Students presented models of Harvey House hotels along with descriptions of the areas where Harvey Houses were located, narratives of people connected with Harvey Houses and historical data on the impact of Harvey Houses on the origins of tourism in New Mexico. The presentations addressed a multi-disciplinary approach to education with New Mexico History, biology, English and math classes collaborating on the unit. This approach was supported by the RGHS design efforts and the Smaller Learning Communities grant.

Save Every Slave Club has been introduced at Menlo-Atherton High by students Elizabeth Sherwin & Sydney Young. Their aim is to raise awareness of the 27 million slaves globally, including 200,000 in the U.S. In January, M-A students will see "At the End of Slavery," a film about modern-day slavery -- just one of the initiatives the Club has planned for the spring semester.

U.S. District Court has reversed a decision by the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals in a case that has wide-ranging implications for school districts nationwide. Judge Michael Mosman ruled that Forest Grove School District is not responsible for reimbursing tuition costs for a former student whose parents enrolled the teenager in a private school without first receiving special education services from the district.

The Middletown Health Department will be returning to our schools to vaccinate the remaining students who are interested in receiving the H1N1 vaccine. This will also give us the opportunity to give the 2nd dose of the vaccine to children under the age of 10 as recommended by the CDC. To find a schedule of clinic locations and times, see http://www.middletowncityschools.com/administration/departments/community_relations/. If you are interested in having your child receive the vaccine, please complete the consent form that was sent home with your child yesterday. Even if you sent back a consent form earlier, you need to complete and return this new form to your child's school. If you need a new form, call you school nurse. If you have any questions or concerns about the H1N1 vaccine or the clinics, please call the Middletown Health Department at 513-425-1818.

How to find out about bad weather delays and closings... 1. School delay and closing information will be broadcast as soon as possible via: - All Cincinnati and Dayton commercial television and radio stations - TV Middletown Cable channel 24 - cNotify automated phone system will alert staff and parents. - Middletown City Schools website at www.middletowncityschools.com:=:https://www.middletowncityschools.com/ - All building answering machines will carry the information. 2. All adult classes, building rentals and school activities will be canceled on days when school is not in session unless there is a specific announcement to the contrary. 3. If school is on a one hour delay: - All employees are to report to work as soon as they can safely arrive. Some students will arrive at the regular time and it is essential that staff be present. - There will be A.M. Pre School 4. If school is on a two hour delay: - All employees are to report to work as soon as they can safely arrive. Some students will arrive at the regular time and it is essential that staff be present. - There will NOT be A.M. Pre School 5. If school must be dismissed early because of bad weather: Instructions will come from the Central Office. Messages will be broadcast via the communication outlets above. 6. Parents, whose work schedule would prevent them from being present if their child is dismissed early, are advised to have a plan for their students in case of an early dismissal event. http://www.middletowncityschools.com/administration/departments/community_relations/:=:https://www.middletowncityschools.com

The Classical Academy, Escondido Receives Exemplary Independent Study Award! The state department of education announced that The Classical Academy, Escondido was selected to receive the Exemplary Independent Study Recognition Award (EISRA). Over 280 independent-study schools in the state competed for the title. Contestants were judged on teacher quality, curriculum, student test scores and school leadership. The other schools to receive the award were La Entrada High School in Yorba Linda and Tamiscal High School in Marin County. The EISRA is designed to recognize excellent educational practices in schools where independent study is the primary mode of instruction. Eligible applicants must have 75 percent or more of the school’s students enrolled in independent study, a statewide Academic Performance Index rank of 6 or above, and may not be in Program Improvement. Coastal Academy received the award in 2008. For more information on independent study and the EISRA, please visit http://www.cde.ca.gov/sp/eo/is/.:=:https://www.cde.ca.gov/sp/eo/is/. For the California Consortium for Independent Study, please visit http://www.ccis.org.Congratulations Classical Academy!

Volcano Vista High principal Yvonne Garcia agreed to be "taped" by student Senators as part of a fundraiser to help cover the cost of a VVHS student's medical bills. The students raised $1,000 for Alex Roberts who suffered a heart attack this past summer and whose family needs help with their medical bills. Students bought one foot of duct tape for a dollar. The tape was used to attach Ms. Garcia to the wall at lunch Friday. The students watched as the student body officers taped her up. ?They used about five rolls of duct tape.

Anticipation has built all week in the Jenks and Union school districts as their students get ready to watch the biggest football game of the year for both. The Backyard Bowl, the regular-season Jenks-Union football game, is one of the most anticipated of every season. But Friday's rematch is for more — the Class 6A state championship. The two schools have played each other for the state championship six times since 1998.

Jenks versus Union 7:30 p.m. Friday University of Tulsa Chapman Stadium Cost: $7 for adults, $5 for students On TV: Cox cable 610 and 710. A replay will be shown on Fox Sports Oklahoma (Cox channel 27) at 4:30 p.m. Saturday.

Today is World AIDS Day. According to the World Health Organization, more than two million AIDS related deaths were reported globally in 2008 - two million children under the age of 15 now live with HIV. UNM HSC researcher Vojo Deretic, Ph.D., and his molecular genetics team recently discovered how the body's immune system can devour tuberculosis, and might, in the future battle HIV. Check out this video to learn more.

State economists will meet this Friday, Dec. 4, to settle on an updated revenue forecast for the state, for the current and coming years. Lawmakers and the governor will base their respective budgets (including education funding) on the estimates when they begin working on budgets in January. The revenue forecast will be updated again in the spring before legislators vote on their final budget.

Episode 34 of Bryan Living & Learning debuts a new look for the show, as co-hosts Sandy Farris of Bryan ISD and Allen Bruggman with the City of Bryan continue to highlight the activities of the district and community. The Board of Education met on Saturday to review an initial list of about 30 candidates for the position of Superintendent of Schools. They are very encouraged by the strength of the candidate pool as reported by the search consultant. Many candidates submitted their resumes to the search consultant with the understanding that their interest in the position would remain confidential in the early stages of the process. In order to maximize the candidate pool and to increase the probability of finding the best candidates, the Board will respect the privacy of the candidates at this time. Once a list of finalists is determined, the candidates will be disclosed and the public will have an opportunity to participate. http://www.middletowncityschools.com/administration/departments/community_relations/

All classrooms will soon get lockdown kits filled with emergency supplies for students stuck in the classroom for long periods. The kits include water, a windup flashlight, Mylar blankets, food bars, a whistle, dust masks, duct tape, hand sanitizer, toilet paper, feminine products and vinyl gloves. And for those who need it, a plastic toilet seat can be snapped on to the bucket. Included are liner bags with deodorizer and solidifier. Read more in today's Albuquerque Journal.

In what may have been an historic first, all three junior high boys basketball teams played in tournament championship games Saturday. Central and George played each other in the finals of the Gray Division of the Allen Classic in Siloam Springs. Central won 40-31 to remain undefeated at 3-0. George is 2-1. Southwest lost a 62-61 heartbreaker to Ft. Smith Chaffin in the Maroon Division title game.

Highland High's community liaison Angela Williams and HHS parent volunteers have partnered with the Buffalo Soldiers of Albuquerque and the Martin Luther King Commission to provide students and families with free fresh vegetables, fruit and bread each week. They serve more than 100 families and students a week, and so far, have given out more than 90,000 pounds of food. The food comes from the Roadrunner Food Bank, and what and how much is available depends on how much the Food Bank can provide. So give to the Food Bank, or contact Angela Williams at williams_a@aps.edu if you're interested in contributing.

Here is an online article shared with subcribers to School Innovations and Advocacy today! San Diego Unified enters new frontier with Facebook and Twitter SCHOOL INNOVATIONS & ADVOCACY By Allen Young Wednesday, November 18, 2009 One section of San Diego Unified’s new Web site provides an online forum where visitors debate over things like the district’s decision to change its media logo in a time of fiscal hardship. Another area of the Web site provides parents and employees with up-to-the-minute updates on the district’s response to the H1N1 virus. Also available is an event calendar and recurrent messages from the superintendent that include budget updates. San Diego Unified’s new Web site is visited by over 750 “fans” daily, but it didn’t cost the district a penny to build or maintain. That’s because it’s a ‘Facebook’ page, the same Facebook used by over 300 million people worldwide. Bernie Rhinerson, chief district relations officer with San Diego Unified, said he created the page one day last spring in less than an hour. He now spends a couple hours a week updating the site by posting pictures and information taken from a separate blog. “It’s not a lot of work,” he said. “You just upload the district logo and type in basic information and you’re up and running.” San Diego Unified may be the first school district in California to step out into the burgeoning social networking frontier by staking a presence on both Facebook and Twitter. Rhinerson said the district wished to reach out to employees and parents in the 25-to-40 age group who regularly tune in to interactive social Web sites as a primary means of sharing information and keeping in touch with the people around them. “Facebook is a way for people to post comments, tell us what they like and don’t like, and share things with us,” he said. The Web site would be essential in the advent of a crisis situation, said Rhinerson, because late-breaking information could immediately be sent out to mobile phones via Twitter or Facebook. “You need to make use of many tools out there to communicate,” he said. But on a day-to-day basis, the website simply works to maintain a sense of community among interested people and keep them informed on various goings-on around the district. Rhinerson regularly uploads newspaper articles that affect the lives of San Diego Unified’s parents and employees. For example, a recent posting relayed new legislation affecting military families, a demographic that makes up about 10 percent of the district’s students. Rhinerson even had a message for Cabinet Report that we think officially marks the extinction of the printed newsletter. “If you send me your story, I’ll post it to our Facebook page,” he said.

Business leaders, educators, and public officials gathered at the Ferguson Center for the Arts Tuesday for the NNPS Business & Education Summit, an event designed to enlist local businesses and organizations to provide career experiences for students before they finish high school. Robert P. Leber, president of the Newport News Education Foundation, told a crowd of about 350 people that it was in businesses’ self-interest to reach out to students, that it was a way to grow skilled candidates for future jobs. NNPS School Superintendent Ashby Kilgore said a vision of an educated and career-ready workforce could only be realized if businesses open their doors to students. The summit was part of American Education Week observations, which included open houses Tuesday at NNPS schools.

will be developing a long-term strategic plan. The strategic planning will occur in several phases. In January 2010, a cross section of volunteers from business and community, as well as school administration, support staff, teachers, parents, and students will meet to develop the mission, vision, beliefs, objectives, and strategies. Once these components have been developed, action teams, also representative of our school system community, will be formed to develop the strategies. The resulting action plans will enable our school system to move from where we are to where we want to be. We anticipate that the action team plans will be ready by June 2010, with implementation of the plan beginning in the 2010-2011 school year.

Eighteen Redwood High students served breakfast recently to seniors residing at Casa de Redwood in Redwood City. In Carolyn Livengood’s column in the San Mateo Times, she quoted one student as saying she “enjoyed it because I thought the seniors were very appreciative and they made conversation with us,” and another student said he thought it was “a good experience” he would want to have again.

Five Carlmont juniors have been accepted into People to People, a student ambassador program started by Pres. Eisenhower to foster peace and cultural understanding around the world. The five juniors, who were nominated and selected as People to People ambassadors for their leadership contributions to their school and community, include Ashley Chang, Gino Ferrario, Shannon Garrett, Lauren Meier and Zachary Rudolph.

Rep. Gingrich refers to the “Listening and Learning” Tour: “I just want to give you one example that we all visited, because I think every American should understand there is no excuse for accepting failure. We visited the Mastery School in Philadelphia. Second most violent school in the city, 25th percentile in outcome. Three years ago the state became desperate, took over the school, turned it over to Mastery, which is a charter school system. Same building, same students. Three years later, they're in the 86th percentile… Every parent in the country should demand that their child be in a school of that caliber and that the change be now...” Click here for a full transcript of the show, on which Secretary of Education Arne Duncan, Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich, and civil rights leader Rev. Al Sharpton discuss their plans to improve the quality of education in this country:

A commentary written by the mayors of Indianapolis, Ind., Newark, N.J., and Nashville, Tenn., appeared in the October 21 issue of Education Week. It made a strong case for the need for alternative education for many high school students and outlined the programs utilized in those cities. It could have been a description of Springdale's Alternative Learning Center. The ALE does fantastic work and helps students who otherwise would have dropped out of school eventually earn high school diplomas. The mayors said a dropout will earn about $260,000 less during his or her lifetime than a graduate, meaning that person will pay $60,000 less in taxes and will stain our heathcare, criminal-justice and social-wellfare systems. Again, ALE should be saluted for giving students another opportunity to graduate and become productive citizens.

On October 28th, a small group of Click4Life/Ready4TheRoad students and staff were invited to perform at the annual Towards Zero Death (TZD) Conference in Duluth, Minnesota. The TZD Conference is sponsored by the Minnesota Departments of Public Safety and Transportation and invites law enforcers from across the state to discuss the 4 “E”s of safe driving practices: Engineering, Enforcement, Education, and Emergency Medical/Health Services. We got the crowd started and revved up for a 2-day forum to encourage safe driving in the state of Minnesota.

A team of education experts has recommended IPS receive five-year district accreditation. IPS was involved in an extensive review Oct. 19-21 by an AdvancED Quality Assurance Review team. AdvancED is a national group that uses research-based standards to help schools and districts to continuously improve. A final decision on the district’s accreditation status will be made in January 2010.

Congratulations to East High School teacher Jean Biebel who has earn her recertification as a National Board Certified Teacher. Her original certification was in 2000. National Board Certification is part of the growing education reform movement that is advancing student learning, improving teaching and making schools better. Teachers who achieve National Board Certification have met high standards through study, expert evaluation, self-assessment and peer review.

See the Bay News 9 piece featuring Gary Wang! Gary Wang, a Winter Haven resident who was a sixth grader at Jewett Middle Academy. 2009 was the third time in the last four years that Gary recorded perfect scores in both reading and math. Gary did it as a third grader in 2006 at Winter Haven’s Garner Elementary and again as fourth grader in 2007 at Garner. Gary is the only current Polk student on record to have achieved 500 FCAT scores in reading and math more than once.

had a safe & successful suprise fire drill this morning. Fire fighters used dry ice to create "smoke" in one of the school's hallways, but this was no problem for our students & teachers. They calmly re-routed their evacuation using one of the school's alternate routes and arrived safely in the designated meet-up location in our parking lot. Good job, everyone! reports an increase in the number of students with flu-like symptoms. Sanford Elementary Helps to Break World Record On October 8, more than a million children across the United States heard the story “The Hungry Caterpillar.” The campaign was sponsored by Jumpstart, whose goal was to break a world record for the largest shared reading experience in history. In its fourth year, the Read for the Record campaign took place in schools, libraries, stores, hotels, playgrounds, stadiums, offices, and homes across the United States, Mexico, Peru, England, India, and South Africa, as well as other locations. At Sanford Elementary School, Marcia Binns and Diane Legg, members of the school’s Reading Team, read to 440 children. The delightful book by Eric Carle tells of a caterpillar that after eating an enormous amount of food makes a cocoon and eventually turns into a butterfly. To the surprise and squeals of the young listeners, flying paper butterflies emerged as Binns and Legg read the last page of the book, making the experience even more exciting. Two students won the special 40th edition of the book and two others won stuffed caterpillars. Two teachers received flying paper butterflies as souvenirs. Sanford had a “hungry caterpillar” in the main hallway that grew throughout the day as classes told what “they ate” after hearing the story. -- Marcia Binns Hilton, Jenkins, General Stanford, and Saunders also participated in the effort.

Three schools within the Kansas City, Kansas Public Schools have been recognized as 2009 Challenge Award winners. The Challenge Awards are designed to recognize Kansas schools that are making a notable difference in student achievement despite facing significant challenges in their school population. This award recognizes schools for outstanding achievement and uncommon accomplishment based on Kansas Assessment results, the sample size, and the socio-economic status of those taking the test.

32,000 volunteers provided more than 1.7 million volunteer hours and 12,000 students performed 130,000 hours of community service.
The Polk County School Board was named School Board of the Year by the Florida Alliance for the Arts.
The Polk County School District has applied for and received over $315 million in grants over the past five years to benefit students.
The Polk County School Board received the Kennedy Center's Award for excellence in arts education.
Polk County Schools recently received the Top Performer Award from the EPA and U.S. Dept. of Energy for energy conservation.
More than two- thirds of Polk County Schools received an A or B grade from the state in 2009.
Three Polk teachers in the past six years were Florida Teacher of the Year finalists, one winning the state title.
169 seniors attained Superintendent's Scholars status with at least a 3.75 GPA and high scores on the SAT or ACT in 2009.
Polk County Schools is ranked 19th in the nation for the number of National Board Certified Teachers.
28 students were honored for perfect FCAT scores in reading and math in 2009.
In the last five years, Polk had 215 students recognized in various levels of the National Merit Scholar program.

For five consecutive years, the school district has received a Distinguished Budget Presentation Award from the Government Finance Officers Association for satisfying nationally recognized criteria and guidelines.
Over the last three years, the Community Relations Department's efforts to inform and engage the community have resulted in 16 awards from state and local professional PR organizations.
State reports show that Polk has the best energy conservation program among Florida school districts. Polk's energy consumption is the lowest of any Florida school district.
Superintendent Gail F. McKinzie, Ph.D. was named Administrator of the Year by the Florida Music Educators Association.
The Polk County School District was named a Top 100 Employer for African Americans by Black Collegian Magazine.
More than 2,049 classrooms throughout Polk County Public Schools were upgraded with state-of-the-art digital, wireless and audio technology to enhance the learning process.
The Polk County School District's Florida Department of Education grade was a "B" for both 2008 and 2009.
NASA has awarded Polk County Public Schools a $1.4 million grant to enhance the Central Florida Aerospace Academy, an aviation-oriented career academy for high school students.

Hello Heritage fans! The holidays are coming up... how are you planning to keep your kids busy with educational activities over the school break? Here's a few ideas: 1. Cook with your kids! You can promote math skills and teach kids chemistry through cooking. 2. Get creative! Making art with your kids is fun and educational. Teach younger kids about shapes and colors, and older kids about how the brain sees color.

Madison Edgewood created traffic in front of the Delavan-Darien goal all afternoon, and it paid off early and often, the Wisconsin State Journal reported. The Crusaders defeated the Comets 5-1 Saturday (Oct. 24), earning a trip to the boy’s state soccer tournament in Milwaukee and ending Delavan-Darien’s season earlier than hoped. Edgewood jumped out to a 3-0 lead in the sectional final before Chris Doerr broke through the Crusaders’ defense in the 45th minute to make the Comets’ only score of the afternoon. See the full State Journal recap here: http://bit.ly/3d65EZ:=:http://host.madison.com/sports/high-school/soccer/article_63cc580c-c0fc-11de-8ebb-001cc4c03286.html

The annual Sixth-Grade Science Fair at Phoenix Middle School, scheduled for Thursday, Nov. 5, will focus on problem solving in science, organizers say. Capital Improvement Programs & ESPLOST Summaries The Education Special Purpose Location Option Sales Tax (ESPLOST) continuation would authorize the district to levy and collect a one percent sales tax to fund the 2010 Capital Improvement Program, which includes the construction of five new elementary schools, including Heard Elementary; new construction and extensive improvements to athletic facilities at all middle and high schools, including field houses at four high schools; improvements to other schools; improvements in technology; and purchasing new buses. The district, through the ESPLOST, invested more than $300 million in new schools, classroom additions, and facility improvements and upgrades during the 2000 & 2005 Programs. For detailed summaries of the 2000, 2005, and proposed 2010 Capital Improvement Programs, please visit www.bibb.k12.ga.us/splost.html.

State aid to the Ripon Area School District is dropping by $396,000 for the 2009-10 school year. The state’s decision to fund only 60% of the cost of K-12 public education instead of continuing to fund 66.6% of the cost is shifting more of the school district’s budget onto local property taxes. Instead of the planned 1.79% tax increase for the current fiscal year, the Ripon Board of Education must consider an 8.41% increase in the tax levy to make up for the state’s shortfall. The amount that local tax bills will increase depends on local property values in the eleven municipalities that comprise the school district.

The Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction has awarded two charter school grants to the Ripon Area School District for the 2009-10 school year totaling $375,000. Crossroads Academy is receiving a $175,000 implementation renewal grant. The Quest Charter School is receiving a $200,000 planning grant. Both schools are designed around the project-based learning concept.

From the Delavan Enterprise: "Enrollment count bodes well for Delavan-Darien School District." Enrollment numbers are up in the Delavan-Darien School District, which equates to an increase in revenue. October is Disabilities Awareness Month! Did you know that one out of every five Americans has some type of disability? (U.S. Census 2005) Awareness and disability education are crucial in today's society as we become a more diverse population. With more than 80% of our students with special needs being served in the regular education setting, we recognize the need for more awareness on this topic. If you are a parent of a preschool or elementary student with special needs, please join us for "Fundamentals of Special Education," a Parent Night on Wednesday, October 28 from 7:00-8:30 p.m. in the Culbreth Middle School Auditorium. More information at http://www.chccs.k12.nc.us

Newt Gingrich: So Sharpton and the Secretary of Education Arne Duncan and I were in Philadelphia two weeks ago. We were in a school called the Mastery School, named for the Mastery Charter School System. This school, inner-city, African-American, very poor children. This school, three years ago, scored in the 25th percentile. It was so bad that the city of Philadelphia and the state of Pennsylvania took it over and gave it to the charter school. They took over in exactly the same building with exactly the same students. In three years, they changed it so dramatically, that they tested this year in the 86th percentile. Better than many suburban schools. They jumped 61 percentile points in three years, with the same kids. So we are interviewing kids. They would say to us - well the old school was like this, but the new school is like this. They are talking about the same building. But in their minds, it's vividly clear- there was an old school that failed and there is a new school that is successful. In the 11th grade 100 percent of the students plan to go to college. One of the techniques that they use is that every teacher hangs outside his or her room, the flag of the college they graduated from. So if you walk through the hall, you are vividly reminded: here is Penn State, here is the University of Pennsylvania, here is MIT. It is amazing the number of people they are attracting because it is suddenly an exciting place to be.

More than 4,000 people walked down Franklin Street on Saturday afternoon to show their support for public education in Chapel Hill and Carrboro. APS administrators attended a workshop to become knowledgeable of and skillful with the tools of Cultural Proficiency. Cultural Proficiency is about being aware of how we -- as individuals and as organizations -- work with others. It is about being aware of how we respond to those different from us. It is a worldview, a mindset; it is the manner in which we lead our lives.

Got questions on Facebook privacy as the district gets involved in social media? Here's a helpful article on using Facebook settings to get the level of privacy you want with your account. Especially helpful is the information on Friends Lists, which allow you to control which of your friends sees the various information you post. With Friends Lists, for example, you could post one photo album that is visible only to close family members, or an album that is visible only to coworkers. Thanks to Matt Sabin for forwarding this article!

Kathleen Wells: Recently, you joined Secretary of Education Arne Duncan, former House Speaker Newt Gingrich and Rev. Al Sharpton on a "listening and learning" tour in Philadelphia. The tour included a visit to Mastery Charter School, Shoemaker Campus. What did you learn? Congressman Fattah: Shoemaker was a middle school when I went there [and] graduated years ago. It's a high school campus now - from ninth grade through the 12th. It's run through Mastery Charter Schools, a non-profit which runs a couple of schools in my district. The test scores at Shoemaker, prior to Mastery taking charge a few years ago (same kids, same building), were in the 20th percentile in the state. Now they are close to the 90th percentile. They are scoring better and doing better than almost any other school in the whole state of Pennsylvania.It's an alternative management approach. It's a completely college preparatory program. Every kid is expected to prepare themselves to get ready to go on to college.

YES Prep is excited to announce that Eldridge Gilbert will open the 8th YES Prep campus in the summer of 2010. El is a 2005 TeachForAmerica Alum and currently serves as the Dean of Students at YES Prep East End. Not only has El had strong academic success with his students, but has been a campus and district leader in student culture. El is also an MBA candidate at Rice's Educational Entreprenuership Program. Congratulations El. We are proud of you and excited to see what you will accomplish!

For each month in 2009, the Year of Science, we're posting a question. October's theme is Geosciences and Planet Earth. Geoscientists study the composition, structure, and other physical aspects of the Earth. An environmental atlas is a product of geosciences. "Mastery, a former public school transformed into a charter, could be a model for creating better schools and raising student achievement. Since becoming a charter school in 2006, Mastery's test scores at its Shoemaker campus have improved by as much as 50 percent in some subjects. With those impressive results, it is a school worth emulating. That turnaround could be applied to Ackerman's plan to transform 35 failing city schools into district-run charter schools, or put them under new management. Without radical change, public schools will continue to fail too many students." www.philly.com/inquirer/opinion/20091007_Editorial__More_time_for_learning.html:=:http://www.philly.com/philly/opinion/inquirer/20091007_Editorial__More_time_for_learning.html http://www.philly.com/inquirer/opinion/20091007_Editorial__More_time_for_learning.html:=:http://www.philly.com/philly/opinion/inquirer/20091007_Editorial__More_time_for_learning.html

Would you like to make a difference in the life of a young person and close the achievement gap at the same time? Blue Ribbon Mentor-Advocate needs someone like you. Mentoring is a big commitment. We don't try to hide that. But it's also one of the most rewarding things you can do . And it works , our program has a 95% high school graduation rate and 100% of our graduates have gone on to post-secondary education. To learn about the process to become a mentor, visit http://www2.chccs.k12.nc.us/education/dept/dept.php?sectionid=5127.

thanks the many sponsors, donors, volunteers and participants that made the Run to Read 2009 a huge success. The event – held Sept. 27 at Dirksen School in Schaumburg – raised more than $8,000 to support literacy in District 54. Our goal is to collect 1,000 children’s books for every classroom. About 500 people turned out to participate in the 5K race, the 1-mile walk or the 100- and 400-yard dashes for children.

CHCCS will participate in the National Day on Writing on Tuesday, October 20. The event is sponsored by the National Council of Teachers of English (NCTE). An online writing gallery has been created. Students and staff are invited to contribute a selection in any genre in response to the question, "What makes your heart leap up?"The theme is based on William Wordsworth's poem that begins,"My heart leaps up when I behold a rainbow in the sky." For information on how to participate, visit the English/Language Arts website at:http://www2.chccs.k12.nc.us/education/components/scrapbook/default.php?sectiondetailid=43701Questions may be directed to Karyn Gloden at kgloden@chccs.k12.nc.us.

The Albuquerque Publishing Company will serve as a collection point for the PTA clothing bank during the month of October. School District 54 has been selected to appear on www.allthingsplc.info, a website about schools and districts that have built successful Professional Learning Communities (PLCs). District 54 was chosen by a panel of PLC practitioners for this site due to the strides our district has made while using PLC concepts. These concepts include a commitment to student learning, a collaborative culture and a focus on results.District 54 is one of only eight districts listed on the site. In addition to being listed as a district, there are four District 54 schools on the site as well: Enders-Salk, Fairview and Fox elementary schools and Mead Junior High School.

The Chapel Hill-Carrboro City Schools recently completed the collection of data related to the first year of its 2008-2013 District Strategic Plan. A written report of qualitative data was shared with the Board of Education last Thursday night, along with a new set of District Strategic Plan Report Cards. The Report Cards are the tracking mechanism created to monitor district and school progress toward academic priorities. There is a district report card and a report card for each school. The Report Cards track four key areas: Growth, proficiency, the completion of important courses and the graduation rate. View the report cards at http://www2.chccs.k12.nc.us/education/components/docmgr/default.php?sectiondetailid=76517. Dr. Pedersen's blog entry this week also discusses the report cards.

We’re in the midst of the nomination season for Selfless Seniors. For the third year, the APS Education Foundation is looking for the unsung heroes of the Class of 2010, who give back to their communities and take time to help others but haven’t been recognized for their selfless efforts. If you know one of these kids, take a few minutes to nominate him or her. Just go to the APS Education Foundation’s web site (http://www.apseducationfoundation.com:=:http://www.aps.edu/education-foundation) and you’ll find the nomination form. The deadline is Oct. 15. Honorees will have their pictures taken by acclaimed Albuquerque photographer Frank Frost (http://www.frankfrost.com/). Featured in this album are last year's winners.

In order to really capture what it is like to be a first-year teacher at YES Prep, Jeremy Jones and yBlazer Studios have produced an exciting new Podcast series called Year One. Throughout this series, you will be introduced to some of the amazing first-year teachers at YES Prep. You will hear about the successes and challenges they encounter as they work to close the achievement gap in Houston. Our goal in producing Year One is to shed some light on the lives of first-year teachers and spread the word about the amazing work YES Prep Public Schools is doing. Again, we are excited to release our first episode of Year One this morning entitled "Meet Jesse".

After-School Teacher Workday Program is open to all elementary students.The Teacher Workday Program will operate on September 28, October 23, November 2, January 19, February 22, April 5 and May 31. Registration is required, and forms must be submitted at least two weeks before the workday.The program operates at each elementary school. Students are enrolled in the program at the school they attend. The program hours are 7:45 am to 5:45 pm. The fee is $38 per student, per workday and includes two snacks, lunch and activity costs. Field trips and special activities are planned for teacher workdays. Registration information and forms are available at www.chccs.k12.nc.us by clicking on departments, after-school/summer programs and teacher workday program, by stopping by the after-school office at each school or by contacting the Community Schools Office at Lincoln Center at 967-8211, ext. 28266.

APS will formally celebrate the re-opening of Coronado Elementary School from 6-8 p.m., Thursday, Sept. 17, at the school, 601 4th St. SW. Coronado was originally built in 1937 as a Depression-era Works Progress Administration project for $125,000. It has received an $8.3 million renovation that included the construction of a new gym and cafeteria. The original building was turned back into classrooms. It also was updated with the latest technology, including smart boards and computers in each classroom.

Over 30 animals, ranging from chickens to a small pony, were displayed by 15 Springdale High School agricultural students for third graders at Turnbow Elementary despite rainy conditions. The SHS students sheltered the animals under the awning behind Turnbow and shared information about each of the animals with an extremely captive audience. Rabbits, small cows, dogs and a turkey were available for Turnbow's students to pet and ask questions about. It was exciting to watch the delighted third graders learn from SHS students who had raised most of the animals from birth.

It was wonderful to see school board president David Van Bebber speak to over 100 ninth-graders from Springdale's three junior highs at Career Day at Tyson. Van Bebber responded well to the question, "Are you rich?" He asked the student what rich meant to her. After pausing he responded, "I'm rich because of the relationships I have with my family and the people I work with. That's my definition of rich."

Superintendent Winston Brooks is encouraging all APS employees to dig deep as the United Way campaign begins this week. Superintendent Brooks wrote in his weekly message: I wonder whether we could give up two big cups of coffee per pay period. At your corner coffee shop, that would cost about $5, and over the course of the year, would add up to more than $100. If our 14,000 employees averaged a $100 gift to the United Way, the district would realize more than $1 million. To read more of the Superintendent's message, go to: http://www.apsleadership.com/

APS nurses like Kellie Griego of Coronado Elementary School are teaching students ways to prevent the spread of viruses including seasonal and H1N1 flu. Nurse Griego encourages frequent hand washing, and teaches children a song to sing while they are washing their hands (to the tune of "If You're Happy and You Know It Clap Your Hands"): If you cough or you sneeze, wash your hands. If you cough or you sneeze, wash your hands. Use soap and warm water, cause you know you really ought to, If you cough or you sneeze, wash your hands. If you want to stay healthy, wash your hands. If you want to stay healthy, wash your hands. Use soap and warm water, casue you know you really ought to, If you want to stay healthy, wash your hands.

Students at six APS middle schools are taking the challenge to bail one of Mayor Martin Chávez’s dogs out of “jail.” Between now and Sept. 30, Roosevelt, Jackson, Washington, Cleveland, Taylor and Polk middle schools will raise funds to bail out Dukes as part of the United Way of Central New Mexico’s annual campaign. The proceeds benefit the United Way’s general community fund and will be tallied as part of APS’ own campaign for United Way. To give to the campaign, contact the schools. Albuquerque Public Schools kicked off construction of nex+gen Academy – an innovative, high-tech magnet high school – during a groundbreaking ceremony at Monday, Aug. 17, just east of Del Norte High School. Sen. Jeff Bingaman, APS Superintendent Winston Brooks and Michael DeWitte, senior manager/engineer for Sandia National Laboratories, joined APS Board of Education members, administrators, teachers, parents and students in celebrating a revolutionary approach to education. Though nex+gen Academy is located on the Del Norte campus, it is an independent magnet school that will have no attendance boundaries. The school is scheduled to open with about 200 freshmen and sophomores in the fall of 2010. Eventually it will have about 450 students. Students will be selected through a lottery system. Enrollment is scheduled to begin in the spring.

The first day of the school year was rainy, but it didn't dampen spirits at Newport News Public Schools. School Superintendent Ashby Kilgore, School Board Chairman Teddy Hicks, School Board Member Mike Wagner, and administrators helped welcome students at several schools.

Quotes from President Barack Obama's address to students: But at the end of the day, the circumstances of your life – what you look like, where you come from, how much money you have, what you’ve got going on at home . . .That’s no excuse for not trying. Where you are right now doesn’t have to determine where you’ll end up. No one’s written your destiny for you. Here in America, you write your own destiny . . .

What does it mean to be "College Ready?" At Envision Schools, we believe that high school students demonstrate college readiness not only by passing rigorous college prep classes but also by demonstrating their academic knowledge, skills, college work habits and 21st Century Leadership skills by producing "College Ready" products like research papers.

Just got back from the Crawford County Fair where we processed a record 902 “Tool Trade-ups.” The result was a win-win for everyone. Those trading in old pairs of pliers from any manufacturer received a set of brand new CHANNELLOCK® pliers.

Board of Trustees tonight adopted a budget for 2009-10 that includes a state mandated 3% pay raise for teachers as well as a 1 and ½% to 2 % raise for most other employees. The average 3% raise for teachers also includes librarians, counselors, nurses and speech pathologists. The salary increase for District employees who are Director Level III and above was approved at 1 and 1/2%.

's students are all in their places with bright, shining faces! It was so wonderful seeing all the smiles come through the doors this morning. Welcome back, everyone!

Manuel Jara Elementary will initiate the High FIVE (Father’s Imparting Values and Education) Program. Fathers and father figures will be giving “high fives” to families as they enter the building. They will also hand out pencils to students and encourage them to have a fantastic day.

At Dunbar 6th Grade Center, staff will be outside cheering and greeting students and parents as they enter the school. A special room will be set up for parents where breakfast will be served and staff will be available to answer questions.

At Daggett Middle School parents and students will walk the red carpet as they enter the school. There will be greeters outside in formal attire to direct parents and students to a star-studded morning. New students will walk the red carpet into the auditorium to pick up schedules and meet teachers who will be dressed in tuxedos and ball gowns.

schools have special events planned this morning: Luella Merret Elementary will have therapy dogs to soothe kindergarteners' nerves, Daggett Middle School kids and parents will walk a red carpet, Western Hills High School will unveil a new banner. OK folks… we need your help. We’re trying to launch a new program this school year in which we invite key community members to either be a student or a staff member for a day in our district. So, a person could pick to be a 3rd grader for a day, a custodian, a principal, a 10th grader, etc. We just need a catchy name for the program. Any suggestions? Post them below… in comments.

It was a great morning in Midland. Former Secretary of Education Richard Riley said, "Everyone wants a choice in education and you [PA Cyber] are providing a unique choice." And Ohio Senator Tom Sawyer called PA Cyber and NNDS the "gold standard" in cyber education today. How has PA Cyber provided a unique choice for you?

The campus computer network is currently being upgraded. Teachers and staff on campus (hey, what're you doing on campus? It's summer vacation!) may experience outages in network services this week. So if you're not able to log in, sorry. And if you are able to log in...save frequently!

BackPack Attack sets a new record! The 2009 BackPack Attack is thrilled to announce that we have already set a new record! The 2008 drive collected 430,000 supplies. As of the end of the day on Wednesday, August 12, we had counted 453,000 supplies! The best part is we still have an almost full warehouse to count! Thank you so much for your generous contributions.

The 2009 BackPack Attack has ended. Thanks to everyone for dropping off their supplies to the IUPUI warehouse. We hope that we took care of you with friendly faces and in a short time! If you have NOT dropped off your supplies as of Wednesday, August 12, please get them to the warehouse ASAP as we need to get them distributed. Contact Marty Posch at mposch@iupui.edu with any questions.

The NNPS summer-school physical education offering allows students to make room in their school-year schedules for magnet program courses, Advanced Placement or dual-enrollment college classes, and music or other electives. Students who have finished eighth grade can take the class. There are two levels – Outdoor I and Outdoor II – students can take. The first class is a prerequisite for the second, and both classes are offered in both summer-school sessions. Each is worth half a credit. Activities are similar in the two classes, but the advanced class features more challenging activities.
